ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Greatly improved my Spanish written skills while maintaining and practicing my spoken skills.
Developed ability to discuss relevant global issues like culture, the environment in spanish
I made significant progress when it comes to grammar, vocabulary, and an overall ability to engage in discourse using Spanish.
I walked away from this course with more knowledge on Spanish grammar along with an understanding of how to conduct a presentation in Spanish.
I was able to correct my grammar and build my vocabulary.
Some intermediate grammar to help solidify fluency in the Spanish language as well as talking skills gained from presentations and class discussion.
L3 Spanish has a lot more real-life practical applications with much more focus on readings and media compared to L1 and L2 which was more focused on vocabulary and grammar.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the cultural parts of this class learning about Spanish-speaking countries' response to COVID, famous holidays, and reading my first book in Spanish. Projects are more creative and the ELCs are what you make of them.

Strengths - Maripaz was a great instructor and very flexible/helpful; course does not expect any prior knowledge

Weaknesses - not many but maybe the curriculum can be adapted to teach slightly more advanced grammar earlier (which is often useful before L4)
Asynchronous classes on Wednesday were a huge strength, but there were too many presentations.

I loved how this course integrated different forms of media; from reading Spanish literature, watching engaging Spanish videos, and having fun presentations, this course was well rounded in terms of content. However, I wish the course integrated even more experiential learning activities throughout the semester (instead of solely 3) as it is through immersing oneself in different form of Spanish media that enables one to become more fluent.
Too many worksheets, not enough open conversations like in L2

Strengths: great teaching style and class participation
No weaknesses I can think of.
Could be more engaging, wish we focused more on material in class
The course is engaging with daily activities that consistently help with learning Spanish.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Spanish is incredibly useful and Yale teaches it well.
Absolutely, if looking for a low-stress language requirement in a beautiful, useful language
Yes, as long as they want to learn Spanish. It is engaging and challenging, but you will definitely learn a lot.
I would recommend this course to another student looking to improve their Spanish speaking and grammar skills but not to the point of immersion.
Yes
If they need it to complete the language requirement or are very interested in mastering the Spanish language then yes.
YES

I would recommend this class to anyone looking to improve their skills in Spanish. There are engaging assignments and projects and reading had to be one of the most enjoyable parts of this class to me.
